awd_titl_txt: QLCI-CG: Center for a Quantum-Engineered Distributed Computing and Communication Testbed
awd_abstract_narration:
The Quantum Leap Challenge Institutes (QLCI) program is part of the Quantum Leap, one of the research Big Ideas promoted by the National Science Foundation. This award is a QLCI Conceptualization Grant, which supports activities to build capacity among teams planning for the large-scale, interdisciplinary Challenge Institute projects that aim to advance the frontiers of quantum information science and engineering. Research at these Institutes will span the focus areas of quantum computation, quantum communication, quantum simulation, and/or quantum sensing. The Institutes are expected to foster multidisciplinary approaches to specific scientific, technological, and workforce development goals in these fields.
 
This Conceptualization Grant will develop well-formulated plans for a future Challenge Institute proposal along the themes of quantum communication and quantum networking.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to develop the team and the research agenda of an NSF Quantum Leap Challenge Institute full proposal in the 2021 competition. The conceptualization grant allowed us to explore the formation of a very inter disciplinary team, and the process was useful to identify and immerse colleagues in several disciplines that could contribute to the development of a large quantum network across New York state. Besides integrating quantum physicists, our immersion process allowed us to include colleagues in computer science (needed to transfer the ideas of an internet stack to the quantum internet), electrical engineering (needed to develop the in-network control mechanisms), materials science (needed to explore scalability of quantum devices) and psychology (needed to develop a science-based new quantum-smart curriculum). The team developed in this conceptualization grant is a good example of the synergies that can be created among very different disciplines in the context of solving large quantum-centric problems. 

The main goals of our activity were:

1) Establish the foundation of a large quantum-internet-centric proposal targeted at developing the necessary technology and infrastructure to achieve entanglement distribution and processing over long distances.

2) Building a New York-centric interdisciplinary team of quantum researchers and engineers, capable of addressing the different challenges associated with developing a quantum internet testbed.

3) Building a large consortium of interested partners in government and industry, supporting the construction of a quantum internet testbed across New York state.

4) To develop a quantum-smart workforce development program using collaboration with workforce experts from other disciplines beyond physics and engineering.

5) Explore the fusion of our effort with other QLCI conceptualization efforts in New York and other parts of the US.

6) To deliver a competitive proposal incorporating all programmatic aspects, including research coordination, workforce development and industry partnerships.

As part of the activities towards the germination of a center, our efforts lead to several key outcomes:

1) The conceptualization of a New York wide infrastructure development program, aimed at developing the backbone of a future quantum network across New Yor state. This prototype was envisioned to connect three independent quantum local area networks (QLANs) located on Long Island (QLAN A, connecting SBU, Brookhaven National Laboratory and CUNY City College), Upstate New York (QLAN B, connecting SUNY Polytechnic, University at Albany and the Air Force Research Laboratory) and Western New York (QLAN C, connecting Cornell University, UR and UB), forming the backbone of a first-of-its-kind intrastate quantum communication network. 

2) The organization of a seed grant program including several of the partner institutions, aimed at fostering the development of the research teams and to sponsor joint graduate students between the member of the QLCI conceptualization grant. Using the seed grant programs from Stony Brook at Buffalo, a total of 12 cross-disciplinary seed grants were awarded, supporting each of the research packages of the QLCI conceptualization proposal.

3) The creation of a Master of Science in Quantum Science and Technology at Stony Brook University and the development of a new quantum technology laboratory serving undergraduate and first year graduate students.

In the context of the development of a workforce program for the QLCI conceptualization grant, we defined a new core set of classes and a curriculum aimed at students in the physical and engineering sciences. In this new approach to curriculum development, we looked at how physics and engineering students can be merged in a hybrid curriculum covering immersion aspects to quantum science and technology, while also covering aspects of large systems engineering. Currently, the program has received pre-approval from SUNY and the team is finalizing a formal application to the SUNY academic senate. Within this effort, we have created a new quantum-technology-specific laboratory that teaches undergraduate and graduate students the concepts of entanglement creation and distribution, as well as the concepts of qubits creation and manipulation.
